title: 'Sorry about that': DStv streaming drops Springbok fans during first Rugby World Cup match against New Zealand
text:
The Springboks played their first Rugby World Cup match against New Zeeland on Saturday – but some fans couldn't watch it.

DStv is the only broadcaster with the rights for the tournament in South Africa, and its online streaming platform went down.

DStv apologised to customers on social media, saying they should reset their devices.

Visit Business Insider SA's home page for more stories.

Some South Africans were unable to watch the Springboks' match against New Zealand on Saturday when online streaming service DStv Now ran into trouble.

DStv is the only broadcaster with television rights for the Rugby World Cup in South Africa, while state broadcaster SABC is only able to broadcast on radio.

Sorry about that. Please provide a little more detail so that we can assist you promptly: which error message are you currently getting? — DStv Care (@DStvCare) September 21, 2019

When at least some users tried to log into their DStv Now accounts to view the match, they were greeted by a black screen and an apology message.

“Sorry, we’re unable to play this video right, something went wrong on our side,” it read.

When Business Insider South Africa tested the service during the second half of the Springboks match, we received the same apology.

This despite streaming the match being promoted on both the DStv website and social media channels.

Supporters turned to social media to voice their outrage.

Kindly accept our sincerest apologies in this regard. Please provide a little more detail so that we can assist you promptly. — DStv Care (@DStvCare) September 21, 2019

#NZLvRSA and then DSTV now decides to stop working, yoh masimba man lawa ???????? pic.twitter.com/DBuUAdVAQ9 — Ndaba ko Mkhulu ???? (@Ntokozo_Nikoe) September 21, 2019

@DStvCare I’m a Premium subscriber, trying to stream the rugby on my laptop. DStv Now worked perfectly last night. Now when I hit Stream, I get this: ?? pic.twitter.com/E2FzP7qihB — Wendy Knowler (@wendyknowler) September 21, 2019

“Dear @DStv, please refrain from advertising if you can't deliver,” reporter Jana Marx tweeted.

“Your DSTV Now app is costing thousands of people the opportunity to support the @Springboks. What a shame.”

Dear @DStv, please refrain from advertising if you can't deliver. Your DSTV Now app is costing thousands of people the opportunity to support the @Springboks. What a shame. @SuperSportTV @MultiChoice https://t.co/Ue87iuN5Rw — Jana Marx (@janamarx04) September 21, 2019

So Dstvnow is down.@DStv incredible timing as always ?? pic.twitter.com/JZBhaue6lF — Tinotenda (@justtinotenda) September 21, 2019

“@DStv incredible timing as always,” @justtinotenda tweeted.

@DStvCare still no access to the DSTV Now android app as of 11:40AM pic.twitter.com/XG6g4ev9Sa — Calvin wade dennis (@Calvin36dennis) September 21, 2019

Through its support twitter page @DstvCares, DStv apologised to hundreds of frustrated users.

“Our tech-team was informed of this issue and it was resolved,” @DStvcare tweeted around half time of the match.

Hi there. Apologies for the delayed response. Our tech-team was informed of this issue and it was resolved. Are you still having issues? — DStv Care (@DStvCare) September 21, 2019

For other users, DStv asked to customers to send more information about the issue, or to restart their devices.

Downdector.com showed that the DStv website started experiencing around 11:00 at the start of the Springboks match.

DStv Now service experienced similar issues in May when customers wanted to stream the 8th season premiere episode of HBO's Game of Thrones.
